titlestmt.author: Daniel Hartwig & Jenny Johnson

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.physloc: Special Collections and University Archives materials are stored offsite and must be paged 36-48 hours in advance. For more information on paging collections, see the department's website: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/spc.html.

accessrestrict.head: Access to Collection
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use. Audio-visual materials are not available in original format, and must be reformatted to a digital use copy.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Stanford University Video Collection (SC1031). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Theodore Geballe was professor of Applied Physics and Materials Science Engineering at Stanford University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three tapes from an interview with Theodore Geballe on superconductivity, November 1988; and four tapes on superconductivity, December 1988, including a levitation experiment, crystal growth, and a meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Video tapes on Amos Nur's research on the Jericho fault, which crosses through Israel, Jordan, and Syria. Includes five source tapes and two edited masters.

did.unittitle: University in Society: Do the Ties Bind

dao.xlink:title: University in Society: Do the Ties Bind

daodesc.p: University in Society: Do the Ties Bind: 1969

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Footage was shot in 1969 and concerns student demonstrations on campus, especially against the military research undertaken at Stanford, and administrative responses to student activism; also included is a campus meeting concerning the Study of Education at Stanford. Individuals featured include Kenneth Pitzer, university president, Richard Lyman, provost, Herbert Packer, vice provost, Willard Wyman Jr., dean of students, and faculty members William Rambo, Raymond Wolfinger, Richard Brody, and Richard Fagan. The students were not identified by name. This film was made as part of a PBS series on American universities; Don Lenzer was the director for this episode on Stanford.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Original 16mm film housed in: Film Collection, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This event was sponsored by the Stanford University Department of English and the Creative Writing Program; Creeley was on campus as part of the celebration of the 6 millionth acquisition of the Stanford University Libraries, represented by the papers of Robert Creeley. Collection includes two master tapes and a viewing copy on VHS. Stanford, CA: Stanford Instructional Television Network, 1993.

scopecontent.p: This event, on October 22, 1993, was part of the celebration of the 6 millionth acquisition of the Stanford University Libraries, represented by the papers of Robert Creeley. Included are two source tapes and one VHS viewing copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A 48-minute compilation of home videos includes footage from a vacation to Florida, the 52nd Annual Tournament of Roses, the 1941 Rose Bowl where Stanford beat Nebraska 21-13, a trip to Californias Death Valley, and an unidentified cattle ranch. The video has no audio.

scopecontent.p: First performance taped at Frost Amphitheater on Oct. 11, 1992; second performance taped at White Plaza on Oct. 12, 1992.

did.unittitle: The Arms race, sources and solutions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wolfgang Panofsky, Director of SLAC, Jeremy Stone, Director, Federation of Atomic Scientists, and Tony Webb, anti-nuclear activist, share their views on issues such as rates of technical advances in the arms race, political and psychological perceptions of adversaries' nuclear capabilities, negative byproducts of the arms race, and recurring questions concerning non-proliferation policies, society's willigness to continue financing or otherwise support the arms race, and the incipient creation of nuclear-free zones. A question-and-answer period follows. Panel discussion presented by Stanford Arms Control and Disarmament Forum at Stanford University on May 28, 1981. Moderated by Phil Farley, former Deputy Director, Arms Control Disarmament Agency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen Band of the British Embassy, and John P. Holdren, Professor of Energy and Resources, Berkeley, debate opposing views concerning the installation of Pershing IIs and Cruise missiles in Europe, the anticipated upsetting of the arms balance, the reduced possibility of arms control and the increased possibility of splitting NATO. Fellow panelist Hilmar Linnenkamp of the West German Defense Ministry and the Institute for East-West Security Studies points out the dramatic changes that have occured in Europe over the last 15 years and predicts that the most decisive factor in the debate will not be numbers of missiles nor nuclear strategies but the political "blood pressure" of Europe and the world. A question-and-answer period follows. Held at Stanford University, November 16, 1983 as part of the Forum on Intermediate Nuclear Forces: Pershing II and Cruise Missiles. Moderated by Coit Blacker of the Center for International Security and Arms Control.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Tribute to Peter Bing" created by Stanford Health Care Education, Stanford University Hospital.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Peter Bing, a member of the Stanford class of 1955, is an active supporter of Stanford University. He served on the Board of Trustees from 1970 to 1981, and 1986 to the present; was a member of the Haas Public Service Center Advisory Committee; and was one of four co-chairs of the Centennial Campaign. Peter Bing received the Stanford Associates' Degree of Uncommon Man Award in 1994.

did.unittitle: The Uncommon Man: Dinner in Honor of Mr. Peter Bing

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1953 the Board of Governors created the degree of Uncommon Man/Uncommon Woman to honor those men and women who have rendered unique and outstanding service to the University. The degree was inspired by a statement made by Herbert Hoover, which said in part: "We believe in equal opportunity for all but we know that this includes the opportunity to rise to leadership in other words, to be uncommon." The degree is not given annually, nor at regularly prescribed intervals, but only when it is truly appropriate to honor someone for rare and extraordinary service to the University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Footage of the dinner honoring Peter Bing, recipient of the Stanford Associates' Degree of Uncommon Man Award in 1994.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Peter Bing, a member of the Stanford class of 1955, is an active supporter of Stanford University. He served on the Board of Trustees from 1970 to 1981, and 1986 to the present; was a member of the Haas Public Service Center Advisory Committee; and was one of four co-chairs of the Centennial Campaign. Peter Bing received the Stanford Associates' Degree of Uncommon Man Award in 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This documentary covers the history of the Hoover Institution, its relationship with Stanford University, as well as past and current debates concerning the Institution's role on campus. Produced by documentary filmmaker Ian Slattery.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace is a public policy think tank and library founded in 1919 by then future U.S. president, Herbert Hoover, an early alumnus of Stanford. The Hoover Institution is a unit of Stanford University, and is located on the campus. The Institution houses a large archive related to President Hoover, World War I, and World War II. Its mission statement outlines its basic tenets: representative government, private enterprise, peace, personal freedom, and the safeguards of the American system.

scopecontent.p: Fornet is a Cuban literary and cinema critic, and also a scriptwriter. Here he talks about Cuban filmmaker Toms Gutirrez Alea's career.

did.unittitle: Library Leadership: Confronting A Tumultuous Future
Stanford Builds For the 21st Century: Reconstruction, Restoration, and Renewal

Shakespeare on the Web: A Collaboration Experiment in Creative Education
Carmen Lomas Garza - Papel Picado Workshop
Palo Alto Weekly Centennial Symposium: The Communications Revolution; Where Are We Headed?
How the Stanford network works: a short course in computer networking / Academic Information Resources

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Philip Almquist, senior systems programmer at Stanford University Network introduces beginners to elementary computer networking in the first tape (80 min.). He includes the basics of TCP/IP, the design of the Stanford network, and sources for further study. The second tape (100 min.) builds on the first, discussing TCP/IP more in depth and topics relevant to host and local network administrators. Also presents an advanced discussion of the design of the Stanford network and looks at its future.

did.unittitle: Multimedia 201: beyond the basics / presented by Apple Computer's Higher Education Department; producer/director/writer, Dean Whitlow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The program looks behind the technology at funding and support for multimedia technology. Shows some of the major successes in higher education - what they are doing and how they got it done.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Highlights from Educom 1992 on the ways in which information technology is changing the future of higher education.

did.unittitle: Multimedia in language and literacy / presented by Apple Computer's Education Group; producer, Robin Garthwait; director, Dean Whitlow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Focuses on the different stages of communication: speaking, listening, writing, reading, and the integral role technology plays. Explores how technology is a catalyst in the language and literacy process and how multimedia facilitates most learning styles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title from cassette label. Video taped presentation from Fernando Soriano's class, ChSt 107, Gangs and violence: application to Chicanos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title from cassette label. Video taped presentation from Fernando Soriano's class, CHSt 107, Gangs and violence: application to Chicanos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Video teleconference designed for librarians, college and university teachers, and information specialists to introduce the Internet and show how it is used to improve information access.

did.unittitle: Managing and using PC memory - Data-Tech Institute

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Explains what the different kinds of memory are, where they come from, and what they can and can't do. Shows what's involved with memory upgrades. Discusses memory manager software products in general: what they do, and how they work, with special emphasis on DOS 5.0's memory manager product. Looks at the power of OS/2 2.0

did.unittitle: With our very own names: celebrating and empowering the voices of a diverse community / Carmen Tafolla

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Tafolla performs a series of brief monologues, portraying a variety of Mexican American characters and focusing on diversity in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tutorial on searching the Lexis/Nexis databases.

Nicols Buenaventura: Cuando el hombre es su palabra

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Storyteller Nicols Buenaventura tells some of his stories and answers questions from the audience.

did.unittitle: Cultural factors in behavior / Amado Padilla

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Amado Padilla discusses issues of cultural change with emphasis on socialization of culture and the way it plays out in people's behavior.

did.unittitle: Historical presence of Chicanos in the Southwest / Carlos Vlez-Ibaez

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A presentation of the early history of the Chicano population in the Southwest.

did.unittitle: Gangs, gender and family considerations / Joan Moore

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joan moore discusses the issues of the role of family and gender in gangs and how they play a part in the differences between gangs and among gang members

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mario Handler, a Latin American documentary filmmaker, discusses his life and his films.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vicky Reich introduces the Digital Libraries Initiative. Terry Winograd presents the Stanford Digital Library Project from a computer scientist's view, covering distributed model (virtual library), designing the "glue" (Middleware), comprehensive models and interfaces, support for distributed sources and services, and automation-agents. Rebecca Lasher gives an overview of the computer science technical report project and summarizes the research on identifying electronic documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rod Hernandez makes a distinction between different types of graffiti artists, focusing on graffiti crew members and reviewing similarities they share with gang members.

did.unittitle: Live and learn: an insider's guide to academic success in college / produced and directed by Britt L. Sjoerdsma for the Center for Teaching and Learning, Stanford University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This dramatic presentation is designed to assist freshman in managing their busy schedules--effective use of time, setting priorities, developing reading and notetaking skills, etc.--in order to be successful in college.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Muralist Ray Patlan gives a tour of the outdoor murals of San Francisco's Mission District.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recorded lecture for Spanish Seminar 389 : Hiojosa & Morales (Stanford University. Dept. of Spanish and Portuguese), by Chicano writer Alejandro Morales, introduced by Luis Leal.

Stanford Undergraduate Scholars Program / video produced by Dan Woodard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This program encourages students to spend a quarter or two with a black professor on exploring some subject of common interest.

did.unittitle: Heritage: A series on the importance of Hispanic culture to contemporary America / producers, Joseph Tovares, Charles Vaughn; director, John Grossenbacher
Toward better schools: choice for the 90's / California State Assembly Committee on Education; produced by San Diego State University and KTVF Television, San Diego

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The proceedings of a forum held in San Diego, on choice for parents and students in the schools.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bishop Desmond Tutu speaks on apartheid at Stanford's Memorial Auditorium on the occasion of the first national Martin Luther King Day holiday. He emphasizes the necessity of the United States issuing economic sanctions against South Africa, saying that blacks are willing to suffer economically in order to receive the political rights they have been denied.

did.unittitle: Lo antisublime posmoderno en "Atame" de Pedro Almodovar: conferencia / Gonzalo Navajas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prof. Navajas analyzes Pedro Almodvar's film "Atame" through an aesthetic and postmodernist perspective.

did.unittitle: Enajenacin e ironia en los personajes de Arlt y Acosta: 5 de mayo de 1991; Alurista / Stanford University, Department of Spanish and Portuguese
Reconstructing the ethical canon in Chicana poetics: 10 de mayo de 1991 / Maria Herrera-Sobek

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture on feminist poetics and the new ethical approach being offered by feminist authors with respect to social relations, sexual relations, and ethics in general.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture given by Carlos Monzivis concerning the practice of journalism in Mexico. He also speaks about the writing and interpretation of historical events.

did.unittitle: Chicano cinema class & Zoot Suit week

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Talks by Luiz Valdez, Issac Artenstein, and Moctezuma Esparza on their films and about their experiences as Chicano filmmakers. Taped March 3, 8, and 15, 1990 at the third annual Zoot Suit Event at Stanford University, sponsored by Casa Zapata and the Chicano Cinema class in March 1990.

did.unittitle: Silent no more, a Chicana's vision for leadership: the 6th Annual Ernesto Galarza lecture series/ by Polly Baca

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After introductions and the awarding of the Ernesto Galarza prizes, Polly Baca lectures on the role in American society of Chicanas and their potential for leadership

did.unittitle: Indirect charges at Stanford University: hearing of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hearing before the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations on indirect cost recovery practices at Stanford University for federal research grants and contracts.

did.unittitle: When the critical "they" are "us" / Juan Bruce-Novoa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture on the literary process in Chicano writing in which Prof. Bruce-Novoa examines Chicano literary works using internal contexts vs. external contexts.

did.unittitle: Poticas feministas a la Mexicana/Chicana: Norma Alarcn

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture on the influences and origins of Chicana poets and feminist poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture by Hispanic literature specialist John Beverly to the Stanford University Dept. of Spanish and Portuguese on the topic of testimony, narrative truth, and Latin American post-modernity in I, Rigoberta Menchu.

did.unittitle: Ideologa e identidad en la narrativa Chicana: Stanford University, Department of Spanish and Portuguese; Lauro Flores

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Explores ideas of ideology and identity in Chicano literature.

did.unittitle: New Mexico literature: a paradigm of reconstruction: Francisco Lomel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lecture given by Francisco A. Lomel focusing on the reconstruction of Hispanic literary heritage in New Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Allen Ginsberg and Gregory Corso reading poems at the Kibuki Theater, San Francisco, Calif., 1982

did.unittitle: Eine Eliteschmiede wird 100 Jahre alt: die Stanford Universitat zwischen forschung und Lehre, Wirtschaft und Politik / ein Film von Dieter Winnhuber; Redaktion, Helmut Engelhardt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape was filmed at Stanford in September/October 1985, on the occasion of the University's Centennial. With interviews of the administration, faculty and students (voiceovers in German), scenes of research, study and social activities, as well as views of the setting of Stanford and its impact on Silicon Valley, this film gives a broad spectrum of the University for a German audience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviewer: Jorge Ruffinelli.

did.unittitle: Memory, cultural identity, and the social imaginary: art of the Chicana/o community / Amalia Mesa-Bains.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Amalia Mesa-Bains presents a series of slides of works by Chicano artists as a counter part to the academic perspective on Chicano studies, demonstrating the role of the Chicano visual art in the development of critical consciousness and the artists' contributions in the construction of cultural identity.

did.unittitle: "Bay Area Veterans of the Civil Rights Movement" event video footage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In April of 2015, Dr. Clayborne Carson, Professor of American History and Director of the Martin Luther King, Jr., Research and Education Institute at Stanford University joined civil rights veterans to share stories and insights from the Freedom Movement. Participants explored how fear and courage affected their social activism and personal life, as well as how family influenced and was impacted by, movement participation.
